<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 645, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 128, 747, 445]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 457, 532, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 489, 146, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 488, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
The metre rule is clamped in position near to the spring. Do **not** change the position of the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 535, 181, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 534, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
Use the set square provided to take readings from the metre rule to determine the unstretched length \(L\) of the coiled part of the spring. Record the value of \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 611, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 643, 183, 661]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 642, 920, 675]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 841, 920, 860]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 792, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light in a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. Refer to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 128, 907, 632]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 643, 534, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 146, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 675, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 721, 180, 739]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 721, 574, 739]]<|/det|>
Draw and label the outline of the block ABCD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 752, 173, 770]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 752, 920, 785]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and draw the normal NL at the centre of side AB. Continue the normal so that it passes through side CD of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 800, 180, 817]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 800, 658, 817]]<|/det|>
Label the point \(\mathbf{F}\) where the normal NL crosses side AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 831, 180, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 831, 660, 848]]<|/det|>
Label the point \(\mathbf{G}\) where the normal NL crosses side CD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 845, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 72, 816, 92]]<|/det|>
• Draw the line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 103, 510, 122]]<|/det|>
• Place the paper on the pin board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 135, 917, 154]]<|/det|>
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 166, 918, 214]]<|/det|>
• Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 2.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 227, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 274, 562, 293]]<|/det|>
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\), \(\mathsf{P}_2\), \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 305, 495, 322]]<|/det|>
• Remove the block and the pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 336, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line through the outline of the block until it extends to just outside the outline of the block. Label the end of the line \(\mathbf{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 396, 628, 415]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{H}\) where the line meets side \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 428, 675, 446]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{J}\) where the line meets the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 459, 379, 477]]<|/det|>
• Draw the line \(\mathbf{FH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

range ............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 569, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the length of time taken for ice cubes to melt when they are placed in water. She uses beakers of water at different temperatures to investigate how the initial temperature of the water affects the time taken for the ice cubes to melt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the initial temperature of the water affects the time taken for the ice cubes to melt. You are **not** required to carry out this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 420, 198]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 228, 227]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 280, 243]]<|/det|>
supply of ice cubes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 260, 258]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ beakers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 285, 273]]<|/det|>
supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 324, 305]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 492, 336]]<|/det|>
• write a list of additional apparatus to use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 494, 368]]<|/det|>
• explain how to carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 487, 399]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 603, 476]]<|/det|>
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
